payload.name: transcendental
payload.core: Start from an accepted fact and infer what must be true for it to be possible (Kantian style). Reasons backward from actuality to necessary enabling conditions. If X is possible or actual, what preconditions must hold?
out: necessary preconditions: conditions without which X cannot exist
architectural must-haves: structural requirements implied by capability
foundational requirements: base-level constraints enabling higher functions
presupposition analysis: implicit assumptions revealed by possibility
proc: state accepted fact: identify X that is actual or demonstrably possible
ask enabling question: 'What must be true for X to be possible?'
derive necessary conditions: identify logically required preconditions
distinguish necessary from sufficient: avoid conflating 'must have' with 'enough to have'
check for hidden presuppositions: uncover implicit framework assumptions
validate against reality: confirm derived conditions match actual world
check: starting fact clearly stated and accepted
each precondition shown necessary (X impossible without it)

diff.deductive: deductive derives conclusions from premises; transcendental derives premises from conclusions
diff.constructive: constructive builds existence proofs; transcendental uncovers existence requirements
diff.meta-reasoning: meta-reasoning selects reasoning modes; transcendental analyzes what makes reasoning possible

fail.name: framework projection
signals: treating model requirements as reality requirements
deriving 'necessary' conditions that alternatives could satisfy
confusing conceptual necessity with empirical necessity
assuming only one possible enabling structure
mitigations: ask 'necessary for my model or necessary in reality?'

ex.starting_fact: Byzantine fault-tolerant consensus is achieved in production systems
ex.enabling_question: What must be true for BFT consensus to be possible?
derived_conditions: n >= 3f + 1 nodes (where f is max faulty)
ex.outcome: Architecture requirements derived from possibility conditions, not ad-hoc decisions
